Country B: Low capital mobility, Expansionary monetary policy, Restrictive fiscal policy
Country C: Low capital mobility, Restrictive monetary policy, Restrictive fiscal policy

Based on the Mundell-Fleming model, which country is most likely to experience appreciation of its domestic currency in the short term?
questions.explanation:
Under the Mundell-Fleming model with FLOATING exchange rates:

Country A (High capital mobility):
• Expansionary monetary → C↓
• Restrictive fiscal → C↓
• Net: Currency depreciates

Country B (Low capital mobility):
• Expansionary monetary → C↓ (increases spending/imports)
• Restrictive fiscal → C↑ (decreases spending/imports)
• Net: INDETERMINATE (opposing effects)

Country C (Low capital mobility):
• Restrictive monetary → C↑ (reduces spending/imports)
• Restrictive fiscal → C↑ (reduces spending/imports)
• Net: Currency APPRECIATES

Key: With HIGH capital mobility, capital flows dominate (monetary policy has bigger impact through interest rates). With LOW capital mobility, trade flows dominate (focus on spending and imports).
keyFormulas: High capital mobility: Capital flows dominate → focus on interest rate effects
Low capital mobility: Trade flows dominate → focus on spending/import effects
Restrictive monetary + Restrictive fiscal (low mobility) = appreciation
questions.yourMistake: Selected Country A — forgot that with high capital mobility, expansionary monetary policy causes depreciation through capital outflows

questions.title: Normalizing Private Company Earnings
questions.question:
Margaret Smith is normalizing the operating income of Lytham Corporation, a small, family-owned company, to compare it with public companies. She notes the following:

1. The CEO's annual salary is $600,000. A similarly qualified CEO at a comparable public company earns $1,000,000.
2. Lytham owns a luxury apartment used by the CEO for business and personal travel. If Lytham were public, the apartment would be sold. Annual operating costs are $200,000 and annual depreciation expense is $200,000.
3. Lytham pays 15% of net income in dividends; Smith believes this would be 50% if Lytham were public.

The required adjustments to normalize Lytham's earnings will result in:

choices.text: A reduction in reported operating income
No change in reported operating income
An increase in reported operating income

questions.explanation:
Item 1 — CEO Salary: Increase SG&A by $400,000 ($1,000,000 – $600,000) to reflect market-rate compensation → Decreases operating income by $400,000.

Item 2 — Apartment: If sold, both operating costs ($200,000) and depreciation ($200,000) would be eliminated → Increases operating income by $400,000.

Item 3 — Dividends: Dividends are NOT a component of operating income, so changing the payout ratio has NO effect on operating income.

Net impact: –$400,000 + $400,000 + $0 = $0 (no change).

Key: Dividends are paid from net income, not operating income. Don't confuse dividend policy with operating adjustments.
keyFormulas: CEO salary normalization: Increase SG&A to market rate
Remove personal-use assets: Eliminate both operating costs AND depreciation
Dividends do NOT affect operating income
questions.yourMistake: Likely forgot that the apartment adjustment offsets the salary adjustment, or incorrectly included dividends as an operating item

questions.title: Equity Value with Control Premium and DLOM
questions.question:
Calcyte is a publicly traded company with an equity value of $9,043 million. Margaret Smith conducts a valuation for a private buyout client interested in purchasing a controlling stake. She determines the relevant discount for lack of control (DLOC) to be 23% and the relevant discount for lack of marketability (DLOM) to be 20%.

After applying the appropriate discounts or premiums, the value of Calcyte's equity (in $ millions) to the private buyout client should be closest to:
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Convert DLOC to a Control Premium
DLOC = 1 – [1/(1 + Control Premium)]
Control Premium = [1/(1 – DLOC)] – 1
Control Premium = [1/(1 – 0.23)] – 1 = 1/0.77 – 1 = 0.2987 or 29.87%

Step 2: Apply Control Premium (add, since buyer gains control)
Step 3: Apply DLOM (subtract, since firm will be private post-buyout)

Value = $9,043 × (1 + 0.2987) × (1 – 0.20)
Value = $9,043 × 1.2987 × 0.80
Value ≈ $9,395 million

Common mistakes:
• A ($8,898): Using DLOC directly as control premium → $9,043 × 1.23 × 0.80
• C ($11,744): Forgetting to apply DLOM → $9,043 × 1.2987
keyFormulas: Control Premium = [1/(1 – DLOC)] – 1
Value = Public Equity × (1 + Control Premium) × (1 – DLOM)
DLOC ≠ Control Premium — must convert!

questions.title: Equity Method: Carrying Value with Excess Purchase Price
questions.question:
On 1 January, RMRL purchased a 30% interest in Begonia Bus Inc.'s outstanding common equity for $12,000,000. The excess purchase price was $2,150,000. Half of the excess was attributable to Begonia's plant and equipment (straight-line depreciation, 10-year remaining useful life, zero residual value), and the other half was attributable to land. RMRL has significant influence over Begonia. Begonia is expected to report net income of $1,500,000 for the current year and not pay any dividends.

The estimated carrying value of RMRL's investment in Begonia at the end of the current year should be:
questions.explanation:
Under the equity method:

Step 1: RMRL's share of Begonia's net income
30% × $1,500,000 = $450,000

Step 2: Amortize excess purchase price for plant and equipment
Excess for P&E = 0.5 × $2,150,000 = $1,075,000
Annual amortization = $1,075,000 / 10 years = $107,500
(Land is NOT amortized)

Step 3: Calculate carrying value
= Purchase price + Share of NI – Amortization of excess
= $12,000,000 + $450,000 – $107,500
= $12,342,500

Common mistakes:
• B ($12,450,000): Forgot to amortize the excess purchase price for P&E
• C ($13,392,500): Used 100% of Begonia's NI instead of 30%
keyFormulas: Equity method: Carrying value = Cost + Share of NI – Dividends – Amortization of excess
Only amortize excess on depreciable assets (P&E), NOT land
Use investor's share (30%) of NI, not 100%
questions.yourMistake: Common error: forgetting to amortize excess purchase price or using 100% of NI

questions.title: Accruals Ratios: BS-Based vs CF-Based Trends
questions.question:
Ahmad reviews the trend in RMRL's accruals ratios over the past two years:

                          Most Recent Year    Year Ago
BS-based accruals ratio      4.3%              0.6%
CF-based accruals ratio      1.7%             –2.5%
Beneish M-score             –1.94             –1.43
Altman Z-score               1.54              1.85

With respect to RMRL's accruals ratios, Ahmad should conclude that:

choices.text: Both the balance-sheet-based and cash-flow-based accruals ratios have improved
The BS-based accruals ratio has deteriorated, but the CF-based accruals ratio has improved
The BS-based accruals ratio has improved, but the CF-based accruals ratio has deteriorated

questions.explanation:
For accruals ratios, use ABSOLUTE VALUES — closer to zero = better quality.

BS-based accruals ratio:
• Year Ago: |0.6%| = 0.6%
• Most Recent: |4.3%| = 4.3%
• Absolute value INCREASED → DETERIORATED

CF-based accruals ratio:
• Year Ago: |–2.5%| = 2.5%
• Most Recent: |1.7%| = 1.7%
• Absolute value DECREASED → IMPROVED

Key insight: The sign doesn't matter for accruals ratios — it's the magnitude (absolute value) that indicates earnings quality. Lower absolute values mean less accrual-based earnings, which is higher quality.
keyFormulas: Accruals ratios: Use ABSOLUTE VALUE to assess
Lower |accruals ratio| = higher earnings quality = improvement
Higher |accruals ratio| = lower earnings quality = deterioration
questions.yourMistake: Likely looked at the direction of the numbers rather than comparing absolute values

questions.title: Defined Benefit Pension: Operating Expense Under IFRS
questions.question:
Anita Daani analyzes KTR Insurance, which reports under IFRS. KTR has a defined benefit pension plan (Plan A). For the most recent year, Plan A had a current service cost of $10 million and a past service cost of $2 million.

For the most recent year, KTR's operating expense (in $ millions) related to Plan A was:
questions.explanation:
Under IFRS, service cost has TWO sub-components:
1. Current service cost: $10 million
2. Past service cost: $2 million

BOTH are recognized as operating expense on the income statement.
Operating expense = $10 + $2 = $12 million

Key distinction — IFRS vs US GAAP:
• IFRS: Past service costs go to P&L immediately as operating expense
• US GAAP: Past service costs go to OCI first, then amortized to P&L over average service lives

If this were US GAAP, the answer would be $10 million (current service cost only).

Wrong answers:
• A ($8): Subtracted past service cost instead of adding
• B ($10): Only included current service cost (US GAAP treatment)
keyFormulas: IFRS: Operating expense = Current service cost + Past service cost
US GAAP: Operating expense = Current service cost only (past service cost → OCI)
This is a common IFRS vs GAAP trap question
questions.yourMistake: Used US GAAP treatment (only current service cost) instead of IFRS treatment (both current + past)

questions.title: Treasury Stock Method: Diluted Shares with RSUs
questions.question:
Daani assesses the dilutive effect of KTR's restricted stock units (RSUs) using the treasury stock method and the following data:

Basic shares outstanding at end of year: 2,700 million
Number of unvested RSUs at end of year: 150 million
Average unrecognized share-based compensation expense: $840 million
Average share price during the most recent year: $7

Using the treasury stock method, KTR's number of diluted shares outstanding at the end of the most recent year (in millions) is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Treasury stock method for RSUs:

Step 1: Start with basic shares = 2,700 million

Step 2: Add unvested RSUs = +150 million

Step 3: Subtract assumed repurchases
= Average unrecognized compensation / Average share price
= $840 million / $7 = 120 million

Diluted shares = 2,700 + 150 – 120 = 2,730 million

The logic: The unrecognized compensation expense represents proceeds the company would theoretically receive. These proceeds are used to 'repurchase' shares at the average market price, reducing the dilutive impact.

Common mistakes:
• B (2,850): Forgot to subtract assumed repurchases
• C (2,970): Added assumed repurchases instead of subtracting
keyFormulas: Diluted shares = Basic + RSUs – (Unrecognized comp expense / Avg share price)
Treasury stock method: Net dilution, not gross dilution
Assumed repurchases reduce the dilutive impact

questions.title: Binomial Tree Calibration: Adjusting Forward Rates
questions.question:
Susanne Blythe is calibrating a binomial interest rate tree to price a default-free 3-year bond with a 3.5% annual coupon priced at par ($100). Interest rate volatility is 10% and branching from each node to a high or low state occurs with equal probability (0.5). The 1-year forward rates at Year 0 and Year 1 are confirmed correct. She needs to determine whether the Year 2 rates require adjustment.

The binomial tree rates are:

Year 0: 2.4500%
Year 1: 3.8784% (up), 3.1754% (down)
Year 2: 5.3534% (up-up), 4.3830% (up-down), 3.5885% (down-down)

Using backward induction, calculate the bond's value at Year 0. Based on your result, in the next calibration iteration Blythe should:

choices.text: Decrease the 1-year forward rates at Year 2 (calculated value is below $100)
Leave the 1-year forward rates at Year 2 unchanged (calculated value equals $100)
Increase the 1-year forward rates at Year 2 (calculated value is above $100)

questions.explanation:
Backward induction from Year 3 to Year 0:

Step 1: Year 3 cash flow at all terminal nodes = coupon + par = $103.50

Step 2: Discount back to Year 2 nodes
Node UU: 103.50 / 1.053534 = $98.2408
Node UD: 103.50 / 1.043830 = $99.1541
Node DD: 103.50 / 1.035885 = $99.9146

Step 3: Year 1 node values (add coupon, take probability-weighted average, discount)
Node U: [3.5 + 0.5(98.2408) + 0.5(99.1541)] / 1.038784
= [3.5 + 98.6975] / 1.038784 = $98.3818
Node D: [3.5 + 0.5(99.1541) + 0.5(99.9146)] / 1.031754
= [3.5 + 99.5344] / 1.031754 = $99.8633

Step 4: Year 0 value
[3.5 + 0.5(98.3818) + 0.5(99.8633)] / 1.024500
= [3.5 + 99.1226] / 1.024500 = $100.1684

Result: $100.1684 > $100.00 (market price)
The model overvalues the bond → Forward rates at Year 2 must be INCREASED to lower the calculated value.
keyFormulas: Backward induction: Value = [Coupon + 0.5(V_up) + 0.5(V_down)] / (1 + rate)
At terminal nodes: Cash flow = Coupon + Par
Calculated > Market → Increase rates; Calculated < Market → Decrease rates
questions.yourMistake: May have confused the direction — if bond value is too high, rates need to go UP (inverse relationship)

questions.title: Negative Convexity: Callable vs Putable Bonds
questions.question:
Blythe evaluates three bonds issued by Y Corporation, all with 3-year maturity and 4.5% annual coupon:

Bond 1: Option-free bond
Bond 2: Putable at 100, one year and two years from now
Bond 3: Callable at 102, one year and two years from now

Which of the bonds issued by Y Corporation is most likely to exhibit negative convexity?
questions.explanation:
Bond 3 (the callable bond) is most likely to exhibit negative convexity.

When rates are HIGH: The call option is far out-of-the-money, so the callable bond behaves like a straight bond with positive convexity.

When rates are LOW: The call option is near or in-the-money, and the bond's price is capped near the call price. This creates negative convexity — the upside is limited while the downside remains.

Negative convexity means: Price gains from rate decreases are SMALLER than price losses from equivalent rate increases.

Bond 1 (option-free): Always has positive convexity.
Bond 2 (putable): Always has positive convexity — the put provides a floor that enhances convexity.
Bond 3 (callable): Exhibits negative convexity when the call is near the money.

Memory aid: Callable = Capped upside = negative Convexity. Putable = Protected downside = Positive convexity.
keyFormulas: Callable bonds: negative convexity when call is near the money
Putable bonds: ALWAYS positive convexity
Option-free bonds: ALWAYS positive convexity
questions.yourMistake: May have confused which embedded option creates negative convexity

questions.title: Implied Interest Cost of a Lease
questions.question:
Sebastian Traver at Feldcroft Inc. evaluates a 10-year helicopter lease with the following terms:
• Monthly payments of $125,000 at the end of each month
• Fair value of helicopter: $15,000,000
• Direct cost incurred by Feldcroft at lease inception: $750,000
• Residual value at end of lease: $8,700,000
• Feldcroft's unsecured incremental borrowing rate: 8%

The implied annual interest cost of the helicopter lease is closest to:
questions.explanation:
The implied interest cost equates the initial cash outflow to the PV of future cash flows.

Using a financial calculator:
PV = –$15,750,000 (fair value $15M + direct costs $750K)
PMT = $125,000
N = 120 (10 years × 12 months)
FV = $8,700,000
Solve for i = 0.5249% per month

Implied annual rate = 0.5249% × 12 = 6.299% ≈ 6.30%

Common mistakes:
• B (7.10%): Excluded the $750,000 direct cost from PV → PV = –$15,000,000
• C (8.00%): Used Feldcroft's incremental borrowing rate instead of calculating the implied rate from the lease cash flows

Key: The implied interest cost is derived from the ACTUAL lease cash flows, not from the borrowing rate. Direct costs must be included in the initial outflow.
keyFormulas: PV = Fair value + Direct costs (total initial outflow)
Solve for monthly rate, then annualize: annual rate = monthly rate × 12
Implied lease rate ≠ incremental borrowing rate
questions.yourMistake: Either excluded direct costs or used the borrowing rate instead of solving for the implied rate

questions.title: Country Spread Model: Equity Risk Premium
questions.question:
Feldcroft has operations in Country A, an emerging market representing 10% of the company's revenue. Traver uses the country spread model (no adjustment for relative volatility) with the following data:

• Current US equity risk premium: 5.94%
• 10-year US Treasury bond yield: 3.50%
• Country A 10-year bond yield (local currency): 7.55%
• Country A 10-year bond yield (denominated in USD): 5.15%

Based on the country spread model, the equity risk premium that should be used in calculating Feldcroft's cost of equity is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Country Spread Model:
ERP = ERP_developed + (λ × Country Risk Premium)

Step 1: Calculate Country Risk Premium
CRP = Yield on Country A bond (in USD) – Yield on US Treasury
CRP = 5.15% – 3.50% = 1.65%

IMPORTANT: Use the USD-denominated bond (5.15%), NOT the local currency bond (7.55%). The local currency bond includes FX risk, which is not a credit spread.

Step 2: Apply exposure weighting
λ = 10% (Feldcroft's revenue exposure to Country A)

Step 3: Calculate ERP
ERP = 5.94% + (0.10 × 1.65%) = 5.94% + 0.165% = 6.105% ≈ 6.11%

Common mistakes:
• B (6.35%): Used local currency bond yield (7.55%) instead of USD-denominated (5.15%)
• C (7.59%): Did not apply λ weighting → 5.94% + 1.65% = 7.59%
keyFormulas: ERP = ERP_developed + (λ × CRP)
CRP = EM bond yield (USD-denominated) – US Treasury yield
Use USD-denominated EM bond, NOT local currency bond
λ = proportion of revenue from the emerging market
questions.yourMistake: Either used the local currency bond or forgot to weight by λ

questions.title: Pro Forma Income Statement: Acquisition Adjustments
questions.question:
Traver prepares a pro forma income statement for Feldcroft's acquisition of a target company. The acquisition will be funded with new debt (including refinancing the target's existing debt). He generates cost synergies. After separating D&A from operating expenses, Traver models the following adjustments:

• Interest expense: Add interest from new debt issuance to the target's current interest expense
• Operating expenses: Add cost synergies to, and subtract cost dis-synergies from, combined operating expenses
• D&A expense: Add amortization of acquired intangible assets to combined D&A

Which of the following balances does Traver most likely model correctly?
questions.explanation:
C is correct — D&A is modeled correctly:
1. Combine acquirer and target D&A ✓
2. Add amortization of acquired intangible assets ✓

A is INCORRECT — Interest expense has errors:
• Traver adds new debt interest to the TARGET's current interest expense
• But the target's debt is being REFINANCED as part of the new debt issuance
• This double-counts the target's pre-acquisition interest expense
• Correct approach: Start with acquirer's interest expense, then add interest on ALL new debt (which already includes refinanced target debt)

B is INCORRECT — Operating expenses have the direction reversed:
• Traver ADDS cost synergies and SUBTRACTS dis-synergies
• This is backwards! Cost synergies are SAVINGS → should REDUCE (subtract from) operating expenses
• Cost dis-synergies are extra costs → should INCREASE (add to) operating expenses
• Correct: Subtract synergies, add dis-synergies
keyFormulas: Pro forma D&A = Combined D&A + Amortization of acquired intangibles
Pro forma OpEx = Combined OpEx – Cost synergies + Dis-synergies
Pro forma Interest = Acquirer interest + Interest on ALL new debt (don't double count target)
questions.yourMistake: May have missed the double-counting of interest or the reversed direction of synergies

questions.title: ML Overfitting: Bias-Variance Tradeoff
questions.question:
Megan Helmer uses machine learning to build a model that categorizes companies by whether their predicted ROE is low or high. The model uses multiple features to explain variations in ROE. The model produces low error rates using training data, but much higher error rates using out-of-sample data.

Helmer's ROE prediction model most likely suffers from:
questions.explanation:
The model has LOW in-sample error but HIGH out-of-sample error → Classic sign of OVERFITTING.

Bias-Variance Tradeoff:
• Bias error (underfitting): Model is too simple, poor fit on BOTH training and test data. High in-sample error.
• Variance error (overfitting): Model is too complex, fits noise in training data. Low in-sample error but high out-of-sample error.
• Base error: Irreducible randomness in the data. Affects both training and test data equally.

Here:
• Low training error → Model fits training data well → NOT underfitting, NOT bias error
• High out-of-sample error → Model doesn't generalize → Overfitting with variance error

The model has learned the noise/idiosyncrasies of the training data rather than the true underlying patterns.
keyFormulas: Low in-sample + High out-of-sample = Overfitting + Variance error
High in-sample + High out-of-sample = Underfitting + Bias error
Base error = irreducible noise (affects both)
questions.yourMistake: May have confused base error (random noise) with variance error (poor generalization from overfitting)

questions.title: Logistic Regression: Probability of Default
questions.question:
Helmer builds a logistic regression model to predict the 1-year probability of default for junk bond issuers using two independent variables: the ratio of debt to total capital (LEVERAGE) and the interest coverage ratio (COVERAGE). The estimated coefficients are:

Intercept: –20.0
LEVERAGE: 65.5
COVERAGE: –35.0

ACME is an issuer with LEVERAGE of 0.8 and COVERAGE of 0.9. Based on the logistic regression model, the probability that ACME defaults within the next year is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Calculate the linear combination
b₀ + b₁×LEVERAGE + b₂×COVERAGE
= –20.0 + 65.5(0.8) + (–35.0)(0.9)
= –20.0 + 52.4 – 31.5
= 0.9

Step 2: Apply the logistic function
P = 1 / (1 + e^(–z)), where z = 0.9
P = 1 / (1 + e^(–0.9))
P = 1 / (1 + 0.4066)
P = 1 / 1.4066
P = 0.7109 ≈ 71%

Common mistakes:
• A (29%): Forgot the negative sign → P = 1/(1 + e^(+0.9)) = 1/3.46 = 29%
• C (90%): Treated as linear regression → P = 0.9 = 90% (didn't apply logistic transform)

Key: The logistic function is P = 1/(1 + e^(–z)), note the NEGATIVE sign in the exponent.
keyFormulas: Logistic: P = 1/(1 + e^(–z)) where z = b₀ + b₁X₁ + b₂X₂
Note the NEGATIVE sign: e^(–z), not e^(+z)
Linear combination first, THEN apply logistic transform
questions.yourMistake: Either forgot the negative sign in e^(–z) or didn't apply the logistic transform at all

questions.title: Regression Assumption Violations: Corrective Action
questions.question:
Helmer builds a linear regression model for manufacturing companies:

Model 1: MARGIN_t = b₀ + b₁×INPUT_t + b₂×LOGISTICS_t + ε_t

where MARGIN is profit margin, INPUT is raw material cost inflation, and LOGISTICS is freight cost inflation. She uses five years of quarterly data for 100 companies.

She makes two observations:
• Observation 1: Significant deviations of residuals from the diagonal in the Q-Q plot
• Observation 2: The null hypothesis of the Breusch-Pagan test is rejected

With respect to Observation 2, this indicates that:

choices.text: A larger sample size should be used
Robust standard errors should be calculated

questions.explanation:
The Breusch-Pagan test:
• H₀: No conditional heteroskedasticity (homoskedastic residuals)
• H₁: Conditional heteroskedasticity is present

Since H₀ is REJECTED → Conditional heteroskedasticity is present.

This means the variance of residuals is related to the independent variables, which:
• Biases the standard errors of coefficients
• Makes t-statistics and F-tests unreliable
• May lead to incorrect inference (too many Type I errors)

Correction: Use ROBUST STANDARD ERRORS (White's heteroskedasticity-consistent standard errors), which adjust the standard errors to account for the heteroskedasticity.

Why not the other choices?
• A: Heteroskedasticity requires correction — can't ignore it
• B: Increasing sample size addresses multicollinearity, not heteroskedasticity
keyFormulas: Breusch-Pagan: H₀ = no conditional heteroskedasticity
Reject H₀ → heteroskedasticity present → use robust standard errors
Larger sample size fixes multicollinearity, NOT heteroskedasticity

questions.title: REIT Valuation: P/AFFO Disadvantage
questions.question:
Sarah Lambert researches REIT A, a hotel REIT. She notes that recent property market transaction volumes have been high. In addition, REIT A has recorded a number of one-time gains and charges.

Lambert considers the potential impact these issues could have on different valuation approaches. The issues Lambert is considering regarding REIT A would pose a disadvantage for which of the following valuation models?
questions.explanation:
P/AFFO is disadvantaged because one-time gains and accounting charges directly affect the income statement, making FFO and AFFO harder to compute and complicating comparisons between companies.

Why NOT the others?

• NAV (A): Actually BENEFITS from high transaction volumes — more property comparables make it easier to estimate net asset values. High transaction volumes = more market data = more reliable NAV.

• DDM (C): Not significantly affected. One-time charges have limited effect on dividend payouts since REITs pay dividends based on taxable income requirements, not accounting income. REITs distribute a high percentage of income by law, and one-time items don't usually change that.

Key: P/AFFO is income-statement-based, so anything that distorts the income statement (one-time items, gains, charges) directly impairs this metric.
keyFormulas: P/AFFO: Disadvantaged by one-time gains/charges (income statement distortion)
NAV: Advantaged by high transaction volumes (more comparables)
DDM: Relatively unaffected by one-time items (dividends are stable)
questions.yourMistake: May have thought NAV would be disadvantaged, but high transaction volumes actually help NAV estimation

questions.title: REIT B: Calculating P/AFFO Multiple
questions.question:
Lambert reviews REIT B, an industrial REIT, and calculates the P/AFFO multiple using the following data (in thousands):

Funds from operations (FFO): $465,419
(Gains)/Losses from sale of depreciable real estate: $22,613
Non-cash (straight-line) rent adjustment: $14,705
Recurring maintenance-type capex and leasing commissions: $33,297
Shares outstanding: 100,000
Current share price: $74.65

The P/AFFO multiple for REIT B is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Calculate AFFO
AFFO = FFO – Non-cash rent adjustment – Recurring maintenance capex & leasing commissions
AFFO = $465,419 – $14,705 – $33,297 = $417,417

IMPORTANT: Do NOT subtract gains/losses from sale of depreciable real estate — those have ALREADY been removed when calculating FFO. Subtracting them again would double-count.

Step 2: Calculate AFFO per share
AFFO/share = $417,417 / 100,000 = $4.17

Step 3: Calculate P/AFFO
P/AFFO = $74.65 / $4.17 = 17.9x

Common mistakes:
• A (16.6x): Only subtracted non-cash rent, forgot maintenance capex
• C (18.9x): Also subtracted gains/losses (double-counting since already removed from FFO)
keyFormulas: AFFO = FFO – Non-cash rent adjustments – Recurring maintenance capex
Do NOT subtract gains/losses again (already excluded from FFO)
P/AFFO = Share price / AFFO per share
questions.yourMistake: Either forgot to subtract maintenance capex or double-counted gains already excluded from FFO

questions.title: BCT Compliance Manual: Independence and Objectivity
questions.question:
Irina Benoit, CFA, starts her own firm (BCT) and writes a compliance manual with three procedures:

Procedure 1: Analysts may accept gifts in the form of business-related entertainment to a maximum value listed by the compliance office.

Procedure 2: For all analysts, the purchase of a company's stock through a private placement is capped at a maximum per private placement as listed by the compliance office.

Procedure 3: When attending meetings at an issuer's headquarters, analysts are allowed to accept modest commercial transportation and hotel accommodation paid by the issuer.

Which procedure in the BCT compliance manual is NOT consistent with the CFA Institute Standards of Professional Conduct?
questions.explanation:
Procedure 3 violates Standard I(B) Independence and Objectivity.

The recommended procedures for Standard I(B) explicitly state: When attending meetings at an issuer's headquarters, members and candidates should PAY FOR their own commercial transportation and hotel charges. No corporate issuer should reimburse members or candidates for air transportation.

Allowing issuers to pay for transportation and hotels creates a conflict of interest that compromises the analyst's independence and objectivity.

Procedure 1 is CONSISTENT: Standard I(B) permits customary, ordinary business-related entertainment as long as it doesn't influence or reward analysts. Setting a maximum value is a recommended practice.

Procedure 2 is CONSISTENT: Standard I(B) recommends formal policies with strict limits on employee purchases through private placements. Capping purchases is appropriate.
keyFormulas: Standard I(B): Analysts must pay their own transportation and hotel when visiting issuers
Business entertainment with value limits = acceptable
Private placement caps = acceptable
Issuer-paid travel/lodging = NOT acceptable
questions.yourMistake: May have thought one of the other procedures was inconsistent, but Procedures 1 and 2 follow recommended practices

questions.title: Multistage Residual Income Valuation
questions.question:
Victoria Lazslo values Firm A using a multistage residual income model. She compiles the following data:

| Item | Value |
|------|-------|
| Constant long-term growth rate | 9.6% |
| Constant long-term ROE | 16.0% |
| Market price per share | $220.00 |
| Book value per share | $166.00 |
| Cost of equity | 12.5% |

Lazslo considers that after Year 10, Firm A's ROE will exhibit mean reversion. She estimates residual income in Year 10 to be $8.38 per share, with a persistence factor of 0.7.

Based on the multistage residual income model, the present value of the estimated terminal value of Firm A's stock is closest to:
keyFormulas: Discount for T-1 periods, NOT T periods
Denominator uses (1 + r - ω), NOT (1 - ω)
questions.yourMistake: Discounted for 10 years instead of 9 years (T-1)

questions.title: Residual Income with Comprehensive Income
questions.question:
Victoria Lazslo values Firm B, a building supplies distributor. Firm B's year-end (Year 0) book value of equity is $111 per share and its cost of equity is 12%. Lazslo forecasts the following per-share data:

| Item | Year 1 | Year 2 |
|------|--------|--------|
| Net income | $26.25 | $31.56 |
| Dividends | $3.80 | $4.57 |
| Other comprehensive income | $0.00 | $2.75 |

Firm B's per-share residual income for Year 2 is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Calculate Book Value at End of Year 1 (= Beginning BV for Year 2)
BV_1 = BV_0 + NI_1 - Div_1 + OCI_1
BV_1 = $111.00 + $26.25 - $3.80 + $0.00 = $133.45

Step 2: Calculate Comprehensive Income for Year 2
Comp Income_2 = NI_2 + OCI_2 = $31.56 + $2.75 = $34.31

Step 3: Calculate Residual Income for Year 2
RI_2 = Comp Income_2 - (r × BV_1)
RI_2 = $34.31 - (12% × $133.45)
RI_2 = $34.31 - $16.01 = $18.30

Common mistakes:
• B ($15.55): Used NI only, forgot to add OCI → $31.56 - $16.01 = $15.55
• A ($14.73): Used END-of-Year 2 BV instead of BEGINNING → $34.31 - (12% × $163.19) = $14.73
keyFormulas: RI = (NI + OCI) - (r × Beginning Book Value)
Use BEGINNING of period BV for equity charge
Include OCI in income for clean surplus compliance
questions.yourMistake: Did not add OCI to net income when calculating comprehensive income

questions.title: Capital Structure Change Impact on Firm Valuation
questions.question:
Clara Connor is valuing Omega Pipeline using a two-stage FCFF model with the following assumptions:

| Item | Value |
|------|-------|
| FCFF for both Year 1 and Year 2 | $1,850 million |
| Expected long-term FCFF growth starting Year 3 | 3.0% |
| Pretax cost of debt | 6.0% |
| Debt-to-assets ratio | 40% |
| Risk-free rate | 3.5% |
| Market equity risk premium | 5.5% |
| ESG equity risk premium | 0.9% |
| Equity beta | 1.4 |
| Corporate tax rate | 25% |

Soon after Connor completes her valuation, Omega announces it will issue debt to buy back equity during Year 1. After incorporating this capital structure change, Connor's FCFF forecasts would most likely be:
questions.explanation:
FCFF is Independent of Capital Structure.

FCFF represents cash flow available to ALL providers of capital BEFORE any financing decisions:
FCFF = EBIT(1 - Tax) + Depreciation - CapEx - ΔWorking Capital

Debt issuance and share repurchases are FINANCING activities — they affect how FCFF is distributed, not the FCFF itself.

| Item | Effect of Higher Leverage |
|------|---------------------------|
| FCFF | UNCHANGED |
| FCFE | Changes (higher in year of debt issuance, lower thereafter) |
| WACC | Changes (different debt/equity weighting) |
| Firm Value | May change (if WACC changes) |

Memory aid: FCFF is what the business generates; capital structure is how you divide it up.
keyFormulas: FCFF is independent of capital structure
FCFE IS affected by capital structure changes
Debt issuance/buybacks are financing activities, not operating
questions.yourMistake: Confused FCFF with FCFE — FCFE changes with leverage, FCFF does not

questions.title: Credit Risk: Bond Default Return
questions.question:
Nathan Moffet purchases a senior unsecured bond issued by Company A at $105.35. The bond has an 8% annual-pay coupon, $100 face value, no embedded options, and three years remaining to maturity (coupon just paid).

He collects the following end-of-period credit data:

| Year | Exposure | Recovery | Loss Given Default |
|------|----------|----------|-----------|
| 1 | $117.57 | $47.03 | $70.54 |
| 2 | $112.85 | $45.14 | $67.71 |
| 3 | $108.00 | $43.20 | $64.80 |

Under a base case scenario where the bond defaults at the end of Year 3, the annualized return on Moffet's investment would be closest to:
questions.explanation:
If default occurs at end of Year 3, the bondholder receives:
• Year 1: $8 coupon
• Year 2: $8 coupon
• Year 3: Recovery value of $43.20 (NO additional coupon — recovery already includes accrued interest)

Solve for IRR:
$105.35 = $8/(1+IRR) + $8/(1+IRR)² + $43.20/(1+IRR)³
IRR = -19.57%

IMPORTANT: The Year 3 recovery of $43.20 is 40% of the $108 exposure. The exposure ($108) already includes principal + accrued coupon. Do NOT add an extra $8 coupon in Year 3.

Common mistakes:
• B (-15.45%): Added extra $8 coupon in Year 3 → $43.20 + $8 = $51.20
• C (-9.29%): Used Loss Given Default ($64.80) instead of Recovery ($43.20)
keyFormulas: Recovery already includes accrued interest — don't double-count coupons
Exposure = Principal + Accrued Interest
Recovery = Exposure × Recovery Rate
questions.yourMistake: Added an extra $8 coupon payment in Year 3 on top of recovery value

questions.title: Credit Default Swap: Settlement Comparison
questions.question:
Nathan Moffet owns $10 million of Bond 1, a 5-year senior unsecured bond issued by Company C. He bought credit protection using a $10 million notional CDS that can be settled physically or by cash. The reference obligation is Bond 1. Company C files for bankruptcy.

| Bond | Seniority | Tenor | Par Value | Current Price |
|------|-----------|-------|-----------|---------------|
| Bond 1 | Senior unsecured | 5 years | $100 | $40 |
| Bond 2 | Senior unsecured | 4 years | $100 | $35 |

Would the two settlement methods result in the same total proceeds for Moffet?

choices.text: No, cash settlement would result in higher total proceeds
No, physical settlement would result in higher total proceeds

questions.explanation:
Step 1: Identify Cheapest-to-Deliver (CTD) bond
Bond 1: $40 (40% of par)
Bond 2: $35 (35% of par) ← CTD (lowest price, same seniority)

Step 2: Cash Settlement
• CDS payoff = Notional × (1 - Recovery of CTD) = $10M × (1 - 35%) = $6.5M
• Sell Bond 1 at market = $10M × 40% = $4.0M
• Total = $6.5M + $4.0M = $10.5M

Step 3: Physical Settlement
• Deliver Bond 1 to CDS seller, receive notional = $10.0M

Cash settlement gives $0.5M more because:
- CDS payoff is based on the CTD (Bond 2 at 35%), but
- Moffet keeps Bond 1 which trades at 40% (higher than CTD)

The protection buyer benefits from cash settlement when they hold a bond trading ABOVE the CTD price.
keyFormulas: Cash settlement: CDS payoff based on CTD + keep your bond
Physical settlement: deliver your bond, receive notional
Cash > Physical when held bond price > CTD price
questions.yourMistake: Assumed both methods always produce the same result — they differ when held bond ≠ CTD

questions.title: Currency Translation: Current Rate Method
questions.question:
Herbert Erikson examines Obsidian AG, a eurozone company (EUR). On 1 January, Obsidian formed Ametrine, a UK subsidiary (GBP), consolidated using the current rate method. The GBP steadily strengthened against the EUR throughout the year. Ametrine was profitable and had positive shareholders' equity in its first year.

On 31 December, after translating Ametrine, Obsidian should have reported a:

choices.text: Foreign exchange loss on its consolidated income statement
Positive translation adjustment on its consolidated balance sheet
Negative translation adjustment on its consolidated balance sheet

questions.explanation:
Current Rate Method key rules:
• Translation adjustment goes to OCI/Equity (NOT income statement) — eliminates choice A
• Creates Net Asset Exposure (Assets > Liabilities when equity is positive)

Effect of foreign currency strengthening:
| FC Movement | Exposure | Translation Adjustment |
|-------------|----------|------------------------|
| FC strengthens | Net asset | POSITIVE |
| FC strengthens | Net liability | Negative |
| FC weakens | Net asset | Negative |
| FC weakens | Net liability | Positive |

Here: GBP strengthened + positive equity (net asset exposure) = Positive translation adjustment on balance sheet.

Why A is wrong: Current rate method reports translation adjustments in OCI/equity, NOT income statement. (Temporal method uses the income statement.)
Why C is wrong: Strengthening FC + net asset exposure = positive, not negative.
keyFormulas: Current rate method: Translation adjustment → OCI/Equity (balance sheet)
Temporal method: Translation gain/loss → Income statement
FC strengthens + net asset exposure = positive CTA

questions.title: Currency Translation: Gross Profit Margin Effect
questions.question:
Herbert Erikson examines Citrine, a Poland-based subsidiary (PLN) of Obsidian AG (EUR), consolidated using the temporal method. The PLN steadily strengthened against the EUR throughout the year. All PP&E and a major portion of inventory sold during the year were acquired when the subsidiary was formed on 1 January.

Citrine's gross profit margin on 31 December was:
questions.explanation:
Temporal Method translation rates for income statement:
• Revenue → Average rate
• COGS (from inventory) → Historical rate
• Depreciation → Historical rate

When PLN strengthens steadily through the year:
• Historical rate (Jan 1) < Average rate < Current rate (Dec 31)
• Revenue translated at HIGHER average rate → larger EUR amount
• COGS translated at LOWER historical rate → smaller EUR amount

Result: Numerator (Revenue - COGS) grows proportionally more than Revenue alone → GPM increases.

Example:
• PLN: Revenue=1000, COGS=600, GPM=40%
• If Historical=0.20, Average=0.25 EUR/PLN:
• EUR Revenue: 1000×0.25=250, EUR COGS: 600×0.20=120
• EUR GPM: (250-120)/250 = 52% > 40%
keyFormulas: Temporal: Revenue at average rate, COGS at historical rate
Strengthening FC → Historical < Average → COGS grows less than Revenue
Result: Higher GPM after translation

questions.title: Active Portfolio: Optimal Risk-Return Combination
questions.question:
Juan Bolton analyzes two actively managed funds. He compiles the following data:

| Metric | Fund X | Fund Y | Benchmark |
|--------|--------|--------|----------|
| Expected annual return | 6.7% | 6.5% | 6.2% |
| Standard deviation | 8.9% | 8.6% | 8.3% |

Fund X's expected active risk is 1.3%. Fund Y's ex ante information ratio is 0.27. The risk-free rate is 2.3%.

The maximum Sharpe ratio that can be achieved by combining Fund Y and the benchmark portfolio is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Calculate Benchmark Sharpe Ratio
SR_B = (6.2% - 2.3%) / 8.3% = 3.9% / 8.3% = 0.4699

Step 2: Fund Y's Information Ratio = 0.27 (given)

Step 3: Maximum combined Sharpe ratio
SR_Combined = √(SR²_B + IR²_Y)
= √(0.4699² + 0.27²)
= √(0.2208 + 0.0729)
= √0.2937
= 0.542 ≈ 0.54

Common mistakes:
• A (0.29): Forgot to take the square root → just computed SR² + IR² = 0.2937
• C (0.74): Added SR and IR linearly → 0.4699 + 0.27 = 0.74
keyFormulas: SR²_Combined = SR²_Benchmark + IR²_Active
Maximum SR = √(SR²_B + IR²)
Don't forget the square root! And don't add linearly!

questions.title: Two-Period Binomial Option Pricing
questions.question:
Qiu Tian values European-style call options on Tara Corp. (non-dividend-paying) using a two-period binomial model:

| Parameter | Value |
|-----------|-------|
| Current stock price | INR 10 |
| Time to expiration | 2 years |
| Risk-free rate (annual) | 5.0% |
| Strike price | INR 12 |
| Up factor per period | 1.50 |
| Down factor per period | 0.67 |

Using the two-period binomial model, the no-arbitrage value of the Tara call option is closest to:
keyFormulas: Work backwards: T=2 → T=1 → T=0
Each step: c = [π×c_up + (1-π)×c_down]/(1+r)
questions.yourMistake: Used single-period model instead of two-period — must calculate values at T=2 first, then work backwards

questions.title: Fair Dealing: Oversubscribed Offering Allocation
questions.question:
Michael Lee is a portfolio manager at Skylark Advisory. His adult sister has a fee-paying account at Skylark managed in the same manner as other clients. Prexel Funds offers a limited number of shares in a previously closed fund (PCSF) to Skylark. Demand from Skylark's suitable clients far exceeds the limited supply. To avoid any conflict of interest, Lee does not allocate any PCSF shares to himself or his sister.

Did Lee violate the Standard relating to fair dealing in his allocation of PCSF shares?

choices.text: Yes, because he should have allocated shares to his sister's account
Yes, because he should have allocated shares to both his sister's and to his account

questions.explanation:
Standard III(B) Fair Dealing:

For oversubscribed/limited offerings:
• Member's OWN account: EXCLUDE (correct to forgo personal allocation)
• Family accounts managed like other clients: INCLUDE (must not be excluded)
• All suitable client accounts: INCLUDE (pro-rata allocation)

Lee was correct to exclude HIMSELF. But his sister's account is explicitly described as 'managed in the same manner as other clients.' Under the Standards, family-member accounts managed similarly to other client accounts should NOT be excluded from buying shares in limited offerings.

The Standard states: 'If the investment professional's family-member accounts are managed similarly to the accounts of other clients of the firm, however, the family-member accounts should not be excluded from buying such shares.'

Why A is wrong: Lee DID violate — by excluding his sister's account.
Why C is wrong: Lee was CORRECT to exclude his own account.
keyFormulas: Member's own account: EXCLUDE from oversubscribed offerings
Family accounts managed as regular clients: INCLUDE in allocation
Family ≠ Member — different treatment under the Standards
questions.yourMistake: Thought excluding all family accounts was correct, but family accounts managed as clients must be included

questions.title: IPO Allocation: Personal Account Participation
questions.question:
Carl Hirayo, CFA, at Summit Investments plans to participate in Tarragon Petroleum's IPO for both his personal account and clients' accounts. He obtains preclearance for personal participation because the IPO is NOT fully subscribed at that time. The offering turns out to be fully subscribed at issue and Summit receives ALL requested shares. Hirayo allocates shares on a pro rata basis among all subscribing accounts, including his own.

With respect to the IPO, does Hirayo violate the Standard relating to priority of transactions?

choices.text: Yes, because he allocates shares to himself
Yes, because he applied for the IPO for his personal account

questions.explanation:
Standard VI(B) Priority of Transactions:

No violation because:
1. IPO was NOT fully subscribed when Hirayo obtained preclearance
2. Summit received 100% of ALL requested shares
3. Allocation was PRO RATA among all subscribers
4. NO CLIENT WAS DISADVANTAGED — every client got their full allocation

The Standard prohibits members from benefiting AT THE EXPENSE of clients. Here, clients received everything they wanted. Hirayo's participation did not reduce any client's allocation.

Why B is wrong: Receiving shares personally is not automatically a violation — the violation occurs only when clients are disadvantaged.
Why C is wrong: Applying for personal IPO participation is permitted. The preclearance process exists for this purpose.
keyFormulas: Priority of transactions = clients must not be disadvantaged
100% fill + pro rata = no violation
Preclearance when not fully subscribed = proper procedure

questions.title: Conflicts of Interest: Compensation Disclosure
questions.question:
Carl Hirayo, CFA, at Summit Investments has two compensation arrangements:

1. A $60,000 performance bonus from Summit if his monthly portfolio performance exceeds that of Summit's other portfolios. He discloses this to existing clients but NOT to prospective clients.

2. A $12,000 reward from Summit after he brought in 20 clients from his previous employer. This reward is paid by Summit and is NOT charged to clients. Hirayo does not disclose this to the clients he brought over.

In relation to his compensation, Hirayo violates the Standards when he fails to disclose:

choices.text: Both the $60,000 bonus and the $12,000 reward

questions.explanation:
Standard VI(A) Disclosure of Conflicts:

$60,000 Performance Bonus — MUST DISCLOSE:
• Creates conflict: incentivizes outperforming other Summit portfolios
• Could lead to excessive risk-taking or front-running other clients
• Disclosed to existing clients ✓ but NOT to prospective clients ✗
• VIOLATION: Must disclose to ALL clients, including prospective

$12,000 Client Recruitment Reward — NO DISCLOSURE REQUIRED:
• NOT a referral fee — paid by employer (Summit), not a third party
• Not charged to clients
• One-time payment for past action, no ongoing conflict
• Standard VI(C) Referral Fees applies to compensation from THIRD PARTIES

The $12,000 is employer compensation for business development, not a referral fee from 'others.'
keyFormulas: Performance bonuses creating conflicts = must disclose to ALL clients (including prospective)
Employer-paid recruitment rewards ≠ referral fees
Referral fees = compensation from THIRD PARTIES for recommendations
questions.yourMistake: Thought both required disclosure — the $12,000 is employer compensation, not a third-party referral fee

questions.title: Record Retention: Scope of Required Records
questions.question:
Summit's record retention policy has the following provisions:

Provision 1: Client meeting notes must be preserved in electronic form; hence, any hard copies must be digitized.

Provision 2: Informal blog posts and short message form posts sourced from the internet do not need to be preserved.

Provision 3: Research reports and all supporting documents have a retention period of three years.

To comply with the Standards, which provision should be amended?
questions.explanation:
Standard V(C) Record Retention:

Provision 1 (Electronic form) — COMPLIANT:
• Records may be kept in electronic or hard copy form
• Digitizing hard copies is acceptable

Provision 2 (Blog posts exempt) — NON-COMPLIANT:
• The Standard states: 'The nature or format of the information does not remove a member's responsibility to maintain a record.'
• ALL investment-related communications must be retained: emails, text messages, blog posts, social media posts
• 'Informal' does not exempt records from retention

Provision 3 (Three-year retention) — COMPLIANT:
• The 7-year recommendation only applies when there is NO firm policy
• Since Summit has a policy (3 years), that policy governs
• 'Firms may implement policies detailing the applicable time frame... Fulfilling such requirements satisfies Standard V(C).'

Why C is wrong: 7 years is only a default recommendation in absence of firm policy.
keyFormulas: ALL formats must be retained (emails, texts, blog posts, social media)
Firm policy governs retention period (not the 7-year recommendation)
7-year recommendation only applies WITHOUT a firm policy

questions.title: Derivatives: No-Arbitrage Bond Forward Pricing
questions.question:
Lucy Wang is a derivatives trader for a South African broker-dealer. All trades use a 30/360 day count convention.

Wang determines the no-arbitrage price of a bond forward contract using the following data:

Exhibit 2:
- Quoted bond price (clean, % of par): 105.0
- Future value of coupon interest (% of par): 4.51
- Accrued interest at contract initiation (% of par): 3.00
- Accrued interest at contract expiration (% of par): 0.75
- Time to forward contract expiration: 90 days
- Annualized risk-free rate: 3.7%
- Conversion factor: 1.0

The no-arbitrage bond forward price (as a percentage of par) is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Bond Forward Price: F₀ = FV[B₀ + AI₀] − AI_T − FVCI

Step 1: Full (dirty) price at initiation = 105.0 + 3.00 = 108.00
Step 2: Future value of spot = 108.00 × (1.037)^(90/360) = 108.00 × 1.00912 = 108.985
Step 3: Forward price = 108.985 − 0.75 − 4.51 = 103.73 ≈ 103.7

Choice A (99.2) subtracts AI₀ instead of adding it and adds AI_T instead of subtracting: [(1.037)^0.25 × (105 − 3)] + 0.75 − 4.51 = 99.17.
Choice C (108.4) ignores FVCI entirely: 108.985 − 0.75 = 108.24.
keyFormulas: F₀ = FV(S₀) − AI_T − FVCI
S₀ (dirty price) = Clean Price + AI at initiation
FV(S₀) = S₀ × (1 + r)^T

questions.title: Equity Valuation: Model Selection for Takeover Target
questions.question:
Charlene Norberg is an analyst for a sell-side firm building valuation models for publicly traded firms.

Firm B has consistently paid dividends and has a large cash balance with growing retained earnings. Norberg believes Firm B is a takeover target because it offers synergies to a main competitor. If a takeover occurs, the new owner will likely change Firm B's dividend payout and will issue debt to maintain capital expenditures. Norberg evaluates the potential takeover from the acquirer's perspective.

Which of the following is the most appropriate model to value Firm B?
questions.explanation:
FCFF is correct because:
1. Takeover situation — acquirer's perspective requires cash flows available to ALL capital providers
2. Capital structure will change — new owner will issue debt, changing debt/equity mix
3. Dividend policy will change — makes DDM unreliable
4. FCFF growth reflects fundamentals more clearly than FCFE when leverage fluctuates; WACC is less sensitive to capital structure changes than cost of equity

FCFE is wrong because it's affected by net borrowing decisions. When capital structure changes, historical FCFE growth rates become less meaningful.
DDM is wrong because dividends will change after acquisition and current policy doesn't reflect future payout.
keyFormulas: FCFF: Use when capital structure is changing or evaluating from acquirer perspective
FCFE: Use when capital structure is stable
DDM: Use when dividends are predictable and no change in control
questions.yourMistake: Selected FCFE. For acquisitions with expected capital structure changes, FCFF is preferred because it represents total cash available to all stakeholders before financing decisions.

questions.title: Equity Valuation: Appropriate Value Definition
questions.question:
Charlene Norberg is an analyst evaluating Firm B, which she believes is a takeover target because it offers synergies to one of its main competitors. If a takeover occurs, the new owner will likely change Firm B's dividend payout and issue debt. Norberg evaluates the potential takeover from the acquirer's perspective.

Which of the following definitions of value would be most relevant for Norberg's valuation estimate for Firm B?
questions.explanation:
Investment value is the value to a SPECIFIC buyer considering synergies.

Intrinsic value = PV of expected future cash flows; going-concern value (no special buyer assumed)
Investment value = Value to a specific buyer including synergies
Fair market value = Price between willing buyer and seller with no compulsion

The vignette states Firm B offers synergies to a specific competitor and Norberg evaluates from the acquirer's perspective. Investment value captures synergy benefits specific to this acquirer and strategic value beyond standalone cash flows.

Investment Value = Intrinsic Value + Value of Synergies

Intrinsic value is wrong because it doesn't capture buyer-specific synergies. Fair market value is wrong because it doesn't account for buyer-specific synergies — transaction price in a takeover will likely exceed fair market value.
keyFormulas: Investment Value = Intrinsic Value + Value of Synergies
Intrinsic value: What company is worth to ANY owner
Investment value: What company is worth to THIS SPECIFIC owner
questions.yourMistake: Selected fair market value. When a specific acquirer's synergies are relevant, investment value is the appropriate concept.

questions.title: Equity Valuation: Normalized Earnings Calculation
questions.question:
Amanda Mond is valuing Delong, a growing company in a cyclical industry with volatile earnings. She normalizes Delong's EPS using the average ROE method.

Exhibit 1:
| Metric | Most Recent Year | Avg Over Most Recent Business Cycle | Long-Term Historical Avg |
| BVPS | EUR 11.2 | EUR 10.5 | EUR 9.6 |
| ROE | 15.0% | 16.0% | 17.5% |

Based on the average ROE method, Delong's normalized EPS is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Average ROE Method: Normalized EPS = Average ROE (over business cycle) × Current BVPS

Normalized EPS = 16.0% × EUR 11.2 = 0.16 × 11.2 = EUR 1.79

Use average ROE from the MOST RECENT BUSINESS CYCLE (16.0%), not long-term historical (17.5%).
Use CURRENT BVPS (11.2), not average BVPS.

Choice C (1.96) uses long-term historical ROE: 17.5% × 11.2 = 1.96
Choice A (1.68) uses average BVPS × average ROE: 16.0% × 10.5 = 1.68, or current ROE × current BVPS: 15.0% × 11.2 = 1.68
keyFormulas: Normalized EPS = Average ROE (business cycle) × Current BVPS
Use MOST RECENT business cycle ROE, not long-term historical
Use CURRENT book value, not average book value
questions.yourMistake: Used long-term historical average ROE (17.5%) instead of most recent business cycle ROE (16.0%). The average ROE method uses business cycle ROE with current BVPS.

questions.title: Equity Valuation: Justified Price Multiple
questions.question:
Amanda Mond uses the following forecasted fundamentals to calculate Delong's justified trailing P/E:
- Dividend payout ratio: 46%
- ROE: 15%
- Required rate of return: 10.8%

Based on Mond's forecasted fundamentals, Delong's justified trailing P/E is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Retention rate b = 1 − payout = 1 − 0.46 = 0.54 (NOT 0.46!)
Step 2: Sustainable growth g = b × ROE = 0.54 × 15% = 8.1%
Step 3: Justified TRAILING P/E = (1 − b)(1 + g) / (r − g)
= (0.46)(1.081) / (0.108 − 0.081)
= 0.4973 / 0.027
= 18.42 ≈ 18.4

Choice B (17.0) is the FORWARD P/E: (1 − b) / (r − g) = 0.46 / 0.027 = 17.04
Choice A (14.8) uses payout ratio AS retention rate: g = 0.46 × 15% = 6.9%, then (0.54)(1.069) / (0.108 − 0.069) = 14.8
keyFormulas: Trailing P/E: P₀/E₀ = (1 − b)(1 + g) / (r − g)
Forward P/E: P₀/E₁ = (1 − b) / (r − g)
b = retention rate = 1 − payout ratio
g = b × ROE
questions.yourMistake: Calculated the FORWARD P/E (17.0) instead of TRAILING P/E (18.4). Trailing P/E includes the (1 + g) factor to convert E₀ to its relationship with current price.

questions.title: Commodities: Spread Identification
questions.question:
Ross Wyman is a portfolio manager planning to add commodities to his client's holdings. He and Tina Becker, a commodity advisor, discuss current market prices for three commodities:

| Item | Commodity 1 | Commodity 2 | Commodity 3 |
| Spot price | $1,688 | $830 | $87.20 |
| Near-term futures price | $1,688 | $835 | $85.90 |
| Farther-term futures price | $1,707 | $835 | $84.60 |

Based on current market prices, which commodity has a negative calendar spread?
questions.explanation:
Calendar Spread = Near-term Futures − Farther-term Futures

Commodity 1: $1,688 − $1,707 = −$19 (NEGATIVE)
Commodity 2: $835 − $835 = $0 (flat)
Commodity 3: $85.90 − $84.60 = +$1.30 (positive)

Only Commodity 1 has a negative calendar spread (contango — futures curve slopes upward).

Do NOT confuse Calendar Spread with Basis:
- Calendar Spread = Near-term futures − Farther-term futures
- Basis = Spot − Futures

Negative calendar spread = Contango
Positive calendar spread = Backwardation
keyFormulas: Calendar Spread = Near-term Futures − Farther-term Futures
Basis = Spot − Futures
Negative calendar spread = Contango
Positive calendar spread = Backwardation
questions.yourMistake: Selected Commodity 3 — likely reversed the formula (Farther − Near) or confused calendar spread with basis.

questions.title: Commodities: Futures Curve Theory
questions.question:
Ross Wyman and Tina Becker discuss Commodity 3, which is in backwardation (Spot: $87.20, Near-term futures: $85.90, Farther-term futures: $84.60).

Becker provides additional information about Commodity 3:
- Hedging demand by consumers currently exceeds hedging demand by producers
- The convenience yield exceeds direct storage costs

Based on the exhibit and Becker's additional information, the shape of the futures price curve of Commodity 3 is most consistent with the:
questions.explanation:
Theory of Storage: Futures Price = Spot + Storage Costs − Convenience Yield
When Convenience Yield > Storage Costs → Futures < Spot = Backwardation ✓

Insurance Theory and Hedging Pressure Hypothesis both predict:
- Backwardation when PRODUCER hedging > Consumer hedging
- Contango when Consumer hedging > Producer hedging

But Commodity 3 has consumer hedging > producer hedging, which these theories would predict leads to CONTANGO — not backwardation!

Since Commodity 3 IS in backwardation despite consumer hedging exceeding producer hedging, only the Theory of Storage is consistent (because convenience yield > storage costs).
keyFormulas: Theory of Storage: Futures = Spot + Storage Costs − Convenience Yield
Insurance/Hedging Pressure: Backwardation when producer hedging > consumer hedging
If hedging conditions contradict observed curve shape → Theory of Storage applies
questions.yourMistake: Selected hedging pressure hypothesis. The vignette states consumer hedging > producer hedging, which under hedging pressure would predict contango — but Commodity 3 is in backwardation. Only Theory of Storage (convenience yield > storage costs) is consistent.

questions.title: Commodities: Index Construction Strategy
questions.question:
Ross Wyman considers investing in a commodity index. His objective is to select the index providing the largest contribution to performance based on two expectations:
1. Trending commodity markets, where outperforming assets continue to go up in price and underperforming assets continue to drift lower
2. No changes in the shapes of forward curves, with some markets currently in backwardation and others in contango

Based on his objective, Wyman should select an index that:

choices.text: Rebalances frequently and contains a large percentage of constituents in backwardation
Rebalances frequently and contains a small percentage of constituents in backwardation
Rebalances infrequently and contains a large percentage of constituents in backwardation

questions.explanation:
Two factors:

1. Rebalancing in trending markets: INFREQUENT rebalancing is better. Frequent rebalancing sells outperformers (which keep rising) and buys underperformers (which keep falling), hurting performance. Infrequent rebalancing lets winners run.

2. Backwardation and roll return: LARGE % in backwardation is better. In backwardation, near-term > farther-term, so rolling futures contracts generates positive roll return. In contango, roll return is negative.

Optimal: Infrequent rebalancing + large % backwardation.

Choice A: Frequent rebalancing hurts in trending markets.
Choice B: Both wrong — frequent rebalancing hurts AND small % backwardation means less positive roll return.
keyFormulas: Trending markets → Infrequent rebalancing (let winners run)
Mean-reverting markets → Frequent rebalancing (sell high, buy low)
Backwardation → Positive roll return
Contango → Negative roll return
questions.yourMistake: Selected frequent rebalancing with small % backwardation. In trending markets, frequent rebalancing forces you to sell winners and buy losers. Backwardation generates positive roll return.

questions.title: Portfolio Management: ETF Cost Calculation
questions.question:
Marietjie Granger works for a South African equity fund manager specializing in ETFs. She wants to make a 6-month tactical investment in ETF X-Ray and determines the expected holding period cost using:

- Bid-ask spread: 0.15%
- One-way commission: 0.10%
- Annual management fee: 0.20%

The expected holding period cost for Granger's investment in ETF X-Ray is closest to:
questions.explanation:
ETF Holding Period Cost = Round-trip Trading Cost + Management Fee for Period

Round-trip commission: 0.10% × 2 = 0.20%
Bid-ask spread (paid once on round trip): 0.15%
Management fee (6 months): 0.20% × (6/12) = 0.10%

Total = 0.20% + 0.15% + 0.10% = 0.45%

Choice B (0.55%) does not prorate the annual fee for 6 months: 0.20% + 0.15% + 0.20% = 0.55%
Choice C (0.60%) doubles the bid-ask spread: 0.20% + 0.30% + 0.10% = 0.60%

Key: Bid-ask spread is paid ONCE on the round trip, commission is paid TWICE, and management fee must be PRORATED for holding period.
keyFormulas: Holding Period Cost = (Commission × 2) + Bid-ask Spread + (Annual Fee × Holding Period)
Bid-ask spread paid ONCE on round trip
Commission paid TWICE (buy + sell)
Management fee prorated for holding period
questions.yourMistake: Did not adjust the annual management fee for the 6-month holding period. Used full 0.20% instead of 0.10%.

questions.title: FSA: Asset Impairment Loss Calculation
questions.question:
Dora Kriser, a financial analyst, evaluates Delphine Industries, a company reporting under IFRS. She is concerned that industry changes may negatively affect one of Delphine's cash-generating units and evaluates:

- Carrying value of cash-generating unit: €18,200,000
- Recoverable amount of cash-generating unit: €17,700,000
- Goodwill allocated to cash-generating unit: €300,000

Based on Kriser's projections, the expected impairment loss for Delphine's cash-generating unit is:
questions.explanation:
IFRS Impairment: Impairment Loss = Carrying Value − Recoverable Amount (if CV > RA)

Impairment Loss = €18,200,000 − €17,700,000 = €500,000

The TOTAL impairment loss is the full difference. Allocation order:
1. First reduce goodwill to zero (€300,000)
2. Then allocate remaining (€200,000) pro-rata to other assets

But the TOTAL impairment loss recognized is still €500,000.

Choice A (€200,000) = Total loss minus goodwill — this is only the loss allocated to other assets AFTER goodwill write-off, not the total.
Choice B (€300,000) = Assumes impairment is limited to goodwill only — wrong.
keyFormulas: IFRS Impairment Loss = Carrying Value − Recoverable Amount
Allocation: First to goodwill, then pro-rata to other assets
Question asks for TOTAL loss, not just loss to specific assets
questions.yourMistake: Calculated €500,000 − €300,000 = €200,000. This is the loss allocated to other assets after goodwill, but the question asks for the TOTAL impairment loss.

questions.title: FSA: Cash Flow Classification Comparison
questions.question:
Dora Kriser evaluates Delphine Industries, which reports under IFRS. She examines Delphine's statement of cash flows and observes that interest paid is classified as an operating activity and interest received is classified as an investing activity. She considers whether these classifications could affect comparisons with competitors reporting under US GAAP.

Is Delphine's classification of interest paid and interest received consistent with competitors that report under US GAAP?

choices.text: No, the classification of interest paid is not consistent
No, the classification of interest received is not consistent

questions.explanation:
Cash Flow Classification Rules:

| Item | IFRS | US GAAP |
| Interest paid | Operating OR Financing | Operating ONLY |
| Interest received | Operating OR Investing | Operating ONLY |
| Dividends paid | Operating OR Financing | Financing ONLY |
| Dividends received | Operating OR Investing | Operating ONLY |

Delphine's interest paid → Operating ✓ (consistent with US GAAP)
Delphine's interest received → Investing ✗ (US GAAP requires Operating)

IFRS provides CHOICE for interest and dividend classification. US GAAP REQUIRES specific classifications with no choice.

US GAAP: Interest (paid AND received) = ALWAYS Operating.
keyFormulas: US GAAP: Interest paid/received = ALWAYS Operating
IFRS: Interest = Choice (Operating/Financing for paid; Operating/Investing for received)
US GAAP: Dividends paid = Financing; Dividends received = Operating
questions.yourMistake: Thought both classifications were consistent. Under US GAAP, interest received MUST be classified as operating — there is no choice.

questions.title: Economics: Forward Contract Mark-to-Market
questions.question:
Jennifer Francis is a currency specialist. All currencies are quoted as numerator currency per unit of denominator currency.

Nine months ago, Stephan Podowski bought EUR 20 million forward against USD by entering a 1-year forward contract at 1.1308 USD/EUR. He wants to calculate the mark-to-market value today.

Current data:
- USD/EUR spot rate: 1.1352/1.1355 (bid/ask)
- 90-day forward points: −14/−12
- Annualized 90-day MRR (Actual/360): USD 0.53%, EUR 0.77%

The mark-to-market value of Podowski's USD/EUR forward contract is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Podowski is LONG EUR (bought EUR forward). To offset, he must SELL EUR forward → use BID side.
Spot bid: 1.1352, Forward points bid: −14

Step 2: All-in forward rate = 1.1352 + (−14/10,000) = 1.1352 − 0.0014 = 1.1338 USD/EUR

Step 3: Cash flow at settlement:
Original: BUY EUR 20M at 1.1308 → Pay USD 22,616,000
Offset: SELL EUR 20M at 1.1338 → Receive USD 22,676,000
Net = USD 22,676,000 − USD 22,616,000 = USD 60,000

Step 4: Discount at USD rate for 90 days:
PV = 60,000 / [1 + 0.0053 × (90/360)] = 60,000 / 1.001325 = USD 59,921

Choice C (115,847): Added forward points instead of subtracting (treated negative as positive): 1.1352 + 0.0014 = 1.1366
Choice B (69,907): Used OFFER rate instead of BID: 1.1355 − 0.0012 = 1.1343
keyFormulas: To offset LONG base currency: use BID (selling)
To offset SHORT base currency: use OFFER (buying)
Forward points are already signed (negative = subtract)
Discount at price currency rate
questions.yourMistake: Added forward points instead of subtracting them. Forward points of −14 means SUBTRACT 0.0014 from spot. The negative sign is already built in.

questions.title: Ethics: Work Product and Employer Obligations
questions.question:
Marcia Garrett is a research analyst at IGMA Investments, a large investment firm that claims compliance with the Standards. Garrett has accepted an offer to join a rival firm.

While at IGMA, Garrett and a colleague developed a quantitative model that was used for industry and company analysis. Garrett considers if she can continue to use the model at her new firm.

Would Garrett violate the Standards if she uses the quantitative model at her new firm?

choices.text: Yes, unless she receives permission from IGMA
Yes, unless she receives written permission from her colleague at IGMA

questions.explanation:
Standard IV(A) Loyalty: Members must act for the benefit of their employer and not deprive their employer of the advantage of their skills and abilities, divulge confidential information, or otherwise cause harm.

Key principle: Work product belongs to EMPLOYER, not the employee — even if the employee created it.

The model was developed while employed at IGMA, used for IGMA's business, and is IGMA's property. Using it at a competitor without IGMA's permission = self-dealing (appropriating employer's property).

Choice A is wrong: The model belongs to IGMA regardless of who developed it.
Choice C is wrong: Permission from the colleague is irrelevant — the model belongs to IGMA (the employer), not individual employees. Only IGMA can authorize its use elsewhere.
keyFormulas: Work product developed during employment = Employer's property
Need EMPLOYER permission (not colleague's) to use elsewhere
Self-dealing = Appropriating employer's business opportunity/information
questions.yourMistake: Selected 'No' — thought the model could be freely used. Any models, research, or IP developed during employment belong to the employer.

questions.title: Fixed Income: CDS Contract Initiation Payment
questions.question:
Liying Wang manages an investment-grade bond portfolio and considers purchasing a senior unsecured bond issued by AHM Manufacturing (AHM01). She purchases protection on the AHM01 bond using a single-name CDS with counterparty XRM Bank.

CDS details:
- Standard annual coupon: 100 basis points
- Current market spread on AHM01: 150 basis points
- Initial CDS contract value: set to zero

The CDS protection that Wang purchases on the AHM01 bond requires:

choices.text: Wang to make an upfront payment
XRM Bank to make an upfront payment

questions.explanation:
CDS contracts trade with standardized fixed coupons (typically 100 or 500 bps). The fair value of protection depends on the actual credit spread.

Here: Coupon = 100 bps (what Wang pays annually), Market spread = 150 bps (what protection is worth).
Wang gets protection worth 150 bps but only pays 100 bps per year. The 50 bps difference must be compensated upfront to set initial CDS value to zero.

Rule:
- Market spread > Coupon → Protection BUYER pays upfront
- Market spread < Coupon → Protection SELLER pays upfront
- Market spread = Coupon → No upfront payment

Approximation: Upfront ≈ (Credit Spread − Coupon) × Duration = (150 − 100) × Duration = 50 bps × Duration

Choice A is wrong: If no upfront payment with a below-market coupon, the seller gives away value for free.
Choice C is wrong: XRM Bank (seller) would only pay upfront if coupon exceeded market spread.
keyFormulas: Upfront ≈ (Credit Spread − Coupon) × Duration
Spread > Coupon → Buyer pays upfront
Spread < Coupon → Seller pays upfront
Upfront payment sets initial CDS value to zero
questions.yourMistake: Selected no upfront payment. CDS standardized coupons rarely match market spreads — the difference is settled via upfront premium.

questions.title: Fixed Income: Structured Bond Issuer Benefits
questions.question:
Nathan Moffet is a fixed-income portfolio manager analyzing credit risk within a corporate bond portfolio. Company B plans to issue a covered bond.

A covered bond is a senior debt obligation of a financial institution that gives recourse to both the originator/issuer and a predetermined underlying collateral pool (the 'cover pool'). The dual recourse to the issuing financial institution and the underlying asset pool has been a hallmark of covered bonds since their inception.

Which of the following is a benefit of the Company B bond from the perspective of the issuer?

choices.text: The bond can have a higher credit rating than Company B's rating
Once fully collateralized, the bond is no longer an obligation of Company B
Any prepaid or non-performing assets in the cover pool do not have to be replaced

questions.explanation:
Covered bonds provide investors with dual recourse: (1) recourse to the issuer — the financial institution remains obligated, and (2) recourse to the cover pool — collateral backing the bond.

Given additional credit enhancements (dual recourse + dynamic cover pool), covered bonds typically receive credit ratings several notches ABOVE the issuing institution. This benefits the issuer through lower borrowing costs and a wider investor base.

Choice B is wrong: The covered bond is an ONGOING obligation. Dual recourse means the issuer NEVER escapes liability — they must make payments even if the cover pool falls short.
Choice C is wrong: The cover pool is DYNAMIC, not static. The issuer MUST replace prepaid and non-performing assets and maintain sufficient cash flows to bond maturity.
keyFormulas: Covered bond: Dual recourse (issuer + collateral pool)
Dynamic cover pool: Issuer must replace prepaid/non-performing assets
Higher rating = Lower borrowing costs for issuer
Issuer liability continues throughout bond life
